user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl:
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No use of any <string.h> functions in the fragment. The code performs a table access via the macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET but does not call memcpy/memmove/strcpy/strlen/etc., so MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (which applies to string handling functions) is not violated. Note: if OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET can index out of bounds that would be a different rule (array-index/undefined-behavior), but it is not a Rule 21.17 violation.
